name: applications_application_addKey
description: Add a key credential to an application. This method, along with removeKey, can be used by an application to automate rolling its expiring keys. As part of the request validation for this method, a proof of possession of an existing key is verified before the action can be performed.  Applications that don’t have any existing valid certificates (no certificates have been added yet, or all certificates have expired), won’t be able to use this service action. You can use the Update application operation to perform an update instead.

customKeyIdentifier.description: A 40-character binary type that can be used to identify the credential. Optional. When not provided in the payload, defaults to the thumbprint of the certificate.

displayName.description: Friendly name for the key. Optional.

endDateTime.description: The date and time at which the credential expires. The DateTimeOffset type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.

key.description: Value for the key credential. Should be a Base64 encoded value. Returned only on $select for a single object, that is, GET applications/{applicationId}?$select=keyCredentials or GET servicePrincipals/{servicePrincipalId}?$select=keyCredentials; otherwise, it is always null.

keyId.description: The unique identifier for the key.

startDateTime.description: The date and time at which the credential becomes valid.The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.

type.description: The type of key credential; for example, Symmetric, AsymmetricX509Cert.

usage.description: A string that describes the purpose for which the key can be used; for example, Verify.

displayName.description: Friendly name for the password. Optional.

endDateTime.description: The date and time at which the password expires represented using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z. Optional.

hint.description: Contains the first three characters of the password. Read-only.

keyId.description: The unique identifier for the password.

secretText.description: Read-only; Contains the strong passwords generated by Azure AD that are 16-64 characters in length. The generated password value is only returned during the initial POST request to addPassword. There is no way to retrieve this password in the future.

startDateTime.description: The date and time at which the password becomes valid. The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z. Optional.

$ul: **customKeyIdentifier**: A 40-character binary type that can be used to identify the credential. Optional. When not provided in the payload, defaults to the thumbprint of the certificate.
**displayName**: Friendly name for the key. Optional.

**endDateTime**: The date and time at which the credential expires. The DateTimeOffset type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.

**key**: Value for the key credential. Should be a Base64 encoded value. Returned only on $select for a single object, that is, GET applications/{applicationId}?$select=keyCredentials or GET servicePrincipals/{servicePrincipalId}?$select=keyCredentials; otherwise, it is always null.
**keyId**: The unique identifier for the key.

**startDateTime**: The date and time at which the credential becomes valid.The Timestamp type represents date and time information using ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.
**type**: The type of key credential; for example, Symmetric, AsymmetricX509Cert.
**usage**: A string that describes the purpose for which the key can be used; for example, Verify.
**client-request-id**: Client request Id as sent by the client application.
**request-id**: Request Id as tracked internally by the service
**client-request-id**: Client request Id as sent by the client application.
**request-id**: Request Id as tracked internally by the service
